title: About
text:
Born and raised in Delaware, I attended the University of Delaware to study Wildlife Conservation and Ecology in my hometown of Newark. During and after earning my undergraduate degree, I took seasonal field jobs from Rhode Island to Florida to work with species such as Wood Thrush, Piping Plovers, Red-cockaded Woodpeckers, white-footed deer mice, and frosted flatwoods salamanders. I eventually settled in Virginia to join the Bulluck Avian Ecology Lab at Virginia Commonwealth University, where I studied Red-headed Woodpecker sex-specific parental care behavior and home range size for my Master’s research. I later honed my data wrangling techniques at the Smithsonian Migratory Bird Center and realized managing wildlife data was the career for me.
I am a certified Associate Wildlife Biologist and enjoy birding in my free time.

title: Code Projects
text:
When I can find the time, I like to tinker! Below are some past and current projects started on the weekends or during internships, mostly made with R or R Shiny. I am currently honing my Python skills and also trying to learn Julia.
I’ve only included my personal projects on this page. To see the R packages I created and maintain for work, check out the official USFWS GitHub.

title: Code Projects
text:
Apps




gardenhelpr







In development 2022-present 

I started this R Shiny app to assist in backyard garden planning. Initially, I had an idea to calculate the mean pH requirements of all of the plants I was hoping to grow in my yard. As I did more research, I learned about the benefits of companion planting (and drawbacks to planting “enemies” together)! When completed, the gardenhelpr app will be able to take a list of plants a user is planning to grow and output both (1) ideal growing conditions (pH, soil, light, etc) as well as (2) any plant relationships and subsequent spacing recommendations.







Colorband Combination Generator







Complete 2020 

Created as a test case for my r-shiny-electron-app repository, this is a simple R Shiny app packaged with Electron that creates random color combinations for bird banding. Colors can be selected based on what’s available in a banding kit, and selections are saved for future use via shinyStore.

title: Code Projects
text:
Miscellaneous




Shiny Electron App Creation Guide


Complete 2020 

I wrote a step-by-step guide to creating a desktop application with R Shiny on both macOS and Windows using Electron.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
In 2017 and 2018, I recorded a few hundred hours of Red-headed Woodpecker (Melanerpes erythrocephalus) videos for my research on parental care behavior as part of my Master’s work with the Bulluck Avian Ecology Lab. Woodpeckers were captured and given special leg bands in unique color combinations so I could tell them apart. Breeding pairs were then recorded at nest cavities from May to August at Fort A.P. Hill, Virginia, USA. I converted some of the most interesting clips into gifs to share with the public. Feel free to use the gifs below under the CC BY-SA License.
Want to learn more? Check out a summary of the results of my research!

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Chick
Older woodpecker chicks often perch at the cavity entrance to watch the world outside.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Cleaning
Most birds clean nestling waste from the nest or nest cavity when chicks are young.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Drumming
Often done for territorial purposes.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Preening
Important for cleanliness and to ensure feathers are in good shape for flying.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Provisioning
Parents must provision, or bring food to, their offspring at the nest cavity.

title: Gif Gallery
text:
Resting
A common behavior also referred to as “nest guarding” when done near the nest.

title: Abby Walter
text:
Abby Walter
     
Howdy, my name is Abby! I’m a Wildlife Biologist and Data Analyst located near Washington, DC. I work for the US Fish and Wildlife Service to process and manage migratory bird data with R and Python.

text:
Thumbnail
Citation

Bulluck, L., B. Nickley, A. Walter, and C. Viverette. 2018. Species co-occurrence patterns among cavity nesting birds across seasons and in a landscapes with varying habitat complexity. title: Red-headed Woodpecker Research
text: I studied parental care behavior, home range size, and feather reflectance of Red-headed Woodpeckers (Melanerpes erythrocephalus) as part of my Master’s work with the Bulluck Avian Ecology Lab.

title: Red-headed Woodpecker Research
text:
Parental care behavior
What do Red-headed Woodpecker moms and dads have in common? Withput plumage or significant size differences, they look virtually idential. And they’re both great parents! Below is a summary of my research using a series of infographics. To learn more, check out my parental care publication.

title: Red-headed Woodpecker Research
text:
Nestling development
My paper’s appendix contains details regarding Red-headed Woodpecker nestling development. Benchmarks in growth can be used in future research to determine chick ages in nests with unknown hatch dates.
